1.verse: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, and Timothy our brother, to the church of God that is at Corinth, with all the saints who are in all Achaia:

2.verse: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

3.verse: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of all encouragement,

4.verse: who encourages us in all our troubles, so that we may be able to encourage those experiencing any trouble with the encouragement with which we ourselves are encouraged by God.

5.verse: For just as the sufferings of Christ overflow to us, so also does the encouragement we receive through Christ overflow.

6.verse: If we are distressed, it is for your encouragement and salvation; if we are encouraged, it is for your encouragement that you experience in your patient endurance of the same sufferings that we also suffer.

7.verse: And our hope for you is firm, because we know that as you share in our sufferings, so also you will share in our encouragement.

8.verse: For we do not want you to be unaware, brothers, about the affliction we suffered in Asia, that we were burdened excessively beyond our power to cope, so that we despaired even of living.

9.verse: Indeed, we had the sentence of death within ourselves, that we should no longer trust in ourselves, but in the God who raises the dead.

10.verse: He delivered us from so great a risk of death and will deliver us. On him we have set our hope that he will deliver us yet again,

11.verse: as you also join in helping us by prayer, so that thanks may be given by many people on our behalf for the gracious gift granted to us through the help of many.

12.verse: For our confidence is this, the testimony of our conscience, that with simplicity and sincerity like that of God, and not with earthly wisdom but by the grace of God, we conducted ourselves in the world, and all the more toward you.

13.verse: Now we are not writing you anything other than what you can read and also understand. But I hope that you will understand fully,

14.verse: just as also you have understood us partially, that we are your source of pride, as you also are ours, in the day of the Lord Jesus.

15.verse: And because of this confidence, I was intending to come to you first, so that you might have a second benefit—

16.verse: through your help, to go on to Macedonia, and from Macedonia to come back to you and to be helped by you on my way to Judea.

17.verse: Therefore when I was planning this, I was not capricious, was I? Or the things I plan, do I plan according to the flesh, so that with me it would be “Yes, yes” and “No, no” at the same time?

18.verse: But as surely as God is trustworthy, our word to you has not been “Yes” and “No.”

19.verse: For the Son of God, Jesus Christ, the one who was proclaimed among you by us—by me, Silvanus, and Timothy—was not “Yes” and “No,” but in him it has always been “Yes.”

20.verse: For all the promises of God find their “Yes” in him; and that is why it is through him that we say our “Amen” to God for his glory.

21.verse: Now God is the one who strengthens us, together with you, in Christ, and has anointed us,

22.verse: and who has also sealed us and given us his Spirit in our hearts as a pledge.

23.verse: I call God as a witness against my soul, that it was to spare you that I did not come again to Corinth.

24.verse: Not that we are ruling over your faith, but we are workers with you for your joy; for by faith you have stood firm.

1.verse: So I decided this within myself, not to come to you again with sorrow.

2.verse: For if I cause you sorrow, then who is there to make me glad except the one made sorrowful by me?

3.verse: And I wrote this very thing so that when I came, I would not have sorrow from those who ought to make me rejoice, having confidence in you all that my joy would be the joy of you all.

4.verse: For out of much distress and anguish of heart I wrote to you, with many tears, not to cause you sorrow but to let you know the love that I have especially for you.

5.verse: But if anyone has caused sorrow, he has caused sorrow not for me, but in some measure—not to overstate the case—for all of you.

6.verse: This punishment on such a person by the majority is enough for him,

7.verse: so that you should rather forgive and console him, lest he be swallowed up by excessive sorrow.

8.verse: So I urge you to show that your love for him is real.

9.verse: For this reason also I wrote you: to discover whether you could stand the test—if in everything you are obedient.

10.verse: Now the one to whom you forgive anything, I also do the same; for indeed, what I have forgiven—if I have forgiven anything—I did so for your benefit in the presence of Christ,

11.verse: lest we be taken advantage of by Satan; for we are not unaware of his intentions.

12.verse: When I came to Troas to proclaim the gospel of Christ, even though a door had been opened for me by the Lord,

13.verse: I had no relief for my spirit, because I could not find my brother Titus there. So I said good-bye to them and went on to Macedonia.

14.verse: But thanks be to God, who is always leading us in triumph in Christ, and through us is making known the fragrance of the knowledge of him in every place.

15.verse: For we are an aroma of Christ to God among those who are being saved. Among those who are perishing

16.verse: we are a deadly fume that kills, but to the former we are a life-giving fragrance that brings life. And who is adequate for ministry like this?

17.verse: For we are not like so many, peddling the word of God. To the contrary, in Christ we speak in the sight of God as men of sincerity, as men sent from God.

1.verse: Are we beginning to recommend ourselves again? We do not need, as some do, letters of recommendation to you or from you, do we?

2.verse: You yourselves are our letter, written on our hearts, known and read by all people;

3.verse: making known that you are a letter of Christ, delivered by us, written not in ink but by the Spirit of the living God, not on tablets of stone but on tablets of human hearts.

4.verse: Such is the confidence we have through Christ toward God.

5.verse: Not that we are adequate in ourselves to consider anything as coming from us, but our adequacy comes from God,

6.verse: who indeed made us adequate as servants of a new covenant, based not on the letter but on the Spirit; for the letter kills, but the Spirit imparts life.

7.verse: Now if the ministry of death, engraved in letters on stones, came with such glory that the Israelites were unable to gaze steadily into the face of Moses due to the glory of his face, fading as it was,

8.verse: how much more glorious will be the ministry of the Spirit?

9.verse: For if there was glory in the ministry of condemnation, how much more will the ministry of righteousness exceed it in glory!

10.verse: For indeed, what had been glorious, in this case has no glory because of the glory that surpasses it.

11.verse: For if what was fading away came with glory, how much more will that which is permanent be filled with glory.

12.verse: Therefore since we have such a hope, we behave with great boldness,

13.verse: and not like Moses who used to put a veil over his face so that the sons of Israel would not gaze at the end of what was fading away.

14.verse: But their minds were closed. For until the present day the same veil remains at the reading of the old covenant. Since the veil is not removed, it is clear that only in Christ is it taken away.

15.verse: But until today, whenever Moses is being read, a veil lies over their heart;

16.verse: yet whenever one turns to the Lord, the veil is removed.

17.verse: Now the Lord is the Spirit, and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom.

18.verse: And we all, with unveiled faces, beholding as in a mirror the glory of the Lord, are being transformed into the same image from one degree of glory to another, just as from the Lord, who is the Spirit.

1.verse: Therefore since we have this ministry, just as we have received mercy, we are not discouraged.

2.verse: But we have renounced shameful hidden deeds. We do not practice cunning, nor do we tamper with the word of God, but by the open declaration of truth we commend ourselves to every person's conscience in the sight of God.

3.verse: But even if our gospel is veiled, it is veiled only to those who are perishing,

4.verse: in whose case the god of this world has blinded the minds of the unbelievers, so that they cannot see the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ, who is the image of God.

5.verse: For we do not proclaim ourselves, but Jesus Christ as Lord, and ourselves as your slaves for Jesus’ sake.

6.verse: For it is the God who said, “Out of darkness light will shine,” who has flooded our hearts with the light of the glorious knowledge of God in the face of Christ.

7.verse: But we have this treasure in clay pots, so that the surpassing power belongs to God and does not come from us.

8.verse: We are under pressure from every side, but not crushed; bewildered, but not driven to despair;

9.verse: persecuted, but not abandoned; knocked down, but not knocked out;

10.verse: always carrying about in the body the dying of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus may also be displayed in our bodies.

11.verse: For we who live are constantly being handed over to death for the sake of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus also may be manifested in our mortal flesh.

12.verse: Thus death is at work in us, but life in you.

13.verse: But since we have the same spirit of faith as that which stands written, “I believed; therefore I spoke,” we too believe, and thus we speak,

14.verse: knowing that the one who raised the Lord Jesus will raise us also with Jesus and bring us, together with you, before him.

15.verse: For all these things are for your sake, so that as grace extends to more and more people, it may increase thanksgiving to the glory of God.

16.verse: So we are not discouraged, but even if our outward man is wasting away, our inward man is being renewed day by day.

17.verse: For our momentary lightness of affliction is producing for us an eternal weight of glory far beyond all comparison,

18.verse: as we look not on what can be seen, but on the unseen; for what can be seen is temporary, but what cannot be seen is eternal.

1.verse: For we know that if our earthly house, the tent we live in, is taken down, we have a building from God, a house not made with hands, eternal, in the heavens.

2.verse: For indeed in this tent we groan, longing to put on our heavenly dwelling place,

3.verse: so that after we have taken off our earthly house we will not be found naked.

4.verse: For while we remain in this tent, we groan and are burdened, not because we want to be unclothed, but clothed, so that what is mortal may be swallowed up by life.

5.verse: The one who prepared us for this very thing is God, who gave us the Spirit as a pledge.

6.verse: Therefore we are always confident, knowing that while we are at home in the body we are away from the Lord,

7.verse: for we live by faith, not by sight.

8.verse: Thus we are confident and would rather be away from the body and at home with the Lord.

9.verse: So then we make it our goal, whether at home or away, to be pleasing to him.

10.verse: For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each one may be repaid according to what he has done while in the body, whether good or bad.

11.verse: Therefore since we know the fear of the Lord, we attempt to persuade others; we stand open to God, and, I trust, also to your conscience.

12.verse: For we are not again recommending ourselves to you but giving you an occasion to boast on our behalf, so that you may be able to answer those who boast of what is seen and not of what is in the heart.

13.verse: For if we are out of our minds, it is for God; if we are of sound mind, it is for you.

14.verse: For the love of Christ controls us, since we have concluded this: that one has died for all; therefore all have died.

15.verse: And he died for all so that those who are living might no longer live for themselves but for the one who died for them and was raised.

16.verse: So from now on we regard no one according to the flesh. Even though we once regarded Christ according to the flesh, yet now we regard him in that way no longer.

17.verse: Therefore if anyone is in Christ, there is a new creation; what is old has passed away; behold, what is new has come!

18.verse: And all this is from God, who has reconciled us to himself through Christ and given us the ministry of reconciliation;

19.verse: that is, God was in Christ reconciling the world to himself, not counting their trespasses against them. And he has entrusted us with the message of reconciliation.

20.verse: Therefore we are ambassadors for Christ, as though God were making his appeal through us. We implore you on behalf of Christ, “Be reconciled to God.”

21.verse: He made him who knew no sin to be a sin-offering for us, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God.

1.verse: Thus as coworkers with him, we urge you not to receive the grace of God in vain.

2.verse: For he says, “In the time of my favor I heard you, in the day of salvation I helped you.” Behold, now is the acceptable time; behold, now is the day of salvation!

3.verse: We do not put a stumbling block in anyone’s way, so that our ministry may not be faulted.

4.verse: Rather, as servants of God, we commend ourselves in every way: in great endurance, in times of affliction, hardship, and distress;

5.verse: in beatings, in imprisonments, in riots, in labors, in times of sleeplessness and hunger;

6.verse: by purity, by knowledge, by patience, by kindness, by the Holy Spirit, by sincere love;

7.verse: by the word of truth, by the power of God; with the weapons of righteousness both for the right hand and for the left;

8.verse: through glory and dishonor, through slander and praise; as deceivers, and yet true men;

9.verse: as unknown, and yet well-known; as dying, and yet—look!—we continue to live; as scourged, and yet not killed;

10.verse: as sorrowing, yet always rejoicing; as poor, yet making many rich; as having nothing, and yet possessing everything.

11.verse: We have opened our mouth freely to you, Corinthians; our heart has been opened wide.

12.verse: We are not withholding our affection from you, but you are withholding yours from us.

13.verse: Now as a fair exchange—I speak as to children—open wide your hearts to us also.

14.verse: Do not be unevenly yoked with unbelievers; for what is there in common between righteousness and lawlessness? Or what fellowship has light with darkness?

15.verse: What harmony is there between Christ and Belial? Or what does a believer have in common with an unbeliever?

16.verse: What agreement can the temple of God have with idols? For we are the temple of the living God; just as God said: “I will dwell in their midst and walk among them; I will be their God and they will be my people.”

17.verse: Therefore, “come out from their midst and be separate,” says the Lord, and “touch no unclean thing; then I will receive you,

18.verse: and I will be a father to you, and you will be sons and daughters to me,” says the Lord Almighty.

1.verse: Since then we have these promises, dear friends, let us cleanse ourselves from every defilement of flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.

2.verse: Make room for us in your hearts; we have wronged no one, we have corrupted no one, we have taken advantage of no one.

3.verse: I do not say this to condemn you, for I have said previously that you are in our hearts; thus we live and die together.

4.verse: I have great confidence in you; I take great pride in you. I am filled with encouragement; I am overflowing with joy in all our distress.

5.verse: For even when we came to Macedonia, our bodies had no rest, but on all sides we were distressed—from the outside came conflicts, from within there were fears.

6.verse: But God, who encourages the downcast, encouraged us with the arrival of Titus.

7.verse: And not only by his arrival but also by the encouragement with which he was encouraged by you, as he reported to us your strong affection, your deep sorrow, your ardent concern for me, so that I rejoiced more than ever.

8.verse: For even if I made you sad by my letter, I do not regret it. Even if I did regret it—for I see that that letter did make you sad, though only for a short time—

9.verse: now I rejoice, not because you were made sad, but because your sadness led to repentance; for you were made sad as God intended, so that in nothing you suffered loss by us.

10.verse: For sadness as intended by God produces a repentance that leads to salvation, leaving no regret; but worldly sadness produces death.

11.verse: For see what eagerness this very thing—this sadness as God intended—has produced in you; what defense of yourselves, what indignation, what alarm, what longing, what deep concern, what punishment! In everything you have proved yourselves to be innocent in this matter.

12.verse: So then, even though I wrote to you, it was not on account of the offender, nor on account of the one offended, but that your earnestness toward us might be revealed to you in the sight of God.

13.verse: Because of this we are encouraged. And in addition to our own encouragement, we rejoiced more than ever at the joy of Titus, because his spirit has been refreshed by all of you.

14.verse: For if I have boasted to him about anything regarding you, I have not been embarrassed, but just as everything we said to you was true, so also our boast to Titus about you has proved true.

15.verse: And his affection for you is even greater when he recalls the obedience of you all, how with fear and trembling you welcomed him.

16.verse: I rejoice because in everything I have complete confidence in you.

1.verse: We want you to know, brothers, about the grace of God shown among the churches of Macedonia,

2.verse: how that in a severe test of affliction, the fullness of their joy and their extreme poverty have overflowed in the richness of their generosity.

3.verse: For—as I can testify—they gave according to their means, and even beyond their means; acting spontaneously,

4.verse: begging us with great insistence for the privilege of joining in this ministry to the saints.

5.verse: And they did this, not simply as we had hoped, but first they gave themselves to the Lord and then to us, by the will of God.

6.verse: So we urged Titus that just as he had previously begun the work, so now he should complete this act of kindness among you.

7.verse: But as you excel in everything—in faith, in speech, in knowledge, in all eagerness, and in the love we have aroused in you—make sure that you excel in this act of kindness.

8.verse: I am not saying this as an order, but as a way of testing the genuineness of your love by comparison with the eagerness of others.

9.verse: For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became poor, so that you by his poverty might become rich.

10.verse: And in this matter I am giving my opinion; for this is beneficial for you, who last year not only began to do this work but also to desire to do it.

11.verse: So now finish doing it, so that your readiness in desiring it may be matched by your completing it, as your means allow.

12.verse: For if the readiness is present, the gift is acceptable according to whatever a person has, not according to what he does not have.

13.verse: For this is not for the ease of others and a burden for you, but a matter of equality;

14.verse: at the present time your abundance should supply what they need, so that then their abundance may supply your need; in this way there will be equality.

15.verse: As it is written, “The one who gathered much did not have a surplus, and the one who gathered little did not have too little.”

16.verse: But thanks be to God who put the same eagerness on your behalf in the heart of Titus,

17.verse: because he not only accepted our request, but being very eager and acting on his own initiative, he is on his way to you.

18.verse: And we sent along with him the brother who is highly respected throughout all the churches for his work in the gospel.

19.verse: And not only this, but he has been appointed by the churches to be our traveling companion as we carry out this act of kindness for the glory of the Lord himself, and to show our readiness.

20.verse: We are taking this precaution so that no one should blame us for the way we are administering this generous gift,

21.verse: for we are concerned to do what is right, not only before the Lord but also before men.

22.verse: And we are sending along with them our brother whom we have often tested in many matters and found to be eager, and now he is all the more eager because of his great confidence in you.

23.verse: As for Titus, he is my companion and fellow worker among you. As for our brothers, they are delegates of the churches, an honor to Christ.

24.verse: Therefore show them openly before the churches the proof of your love and the reason for our pride in you.

1.verse: Now concerning the service to the saints, there is no necessity for me to write to you,

2.verse: for I know your readiness to help, about which I keep boasting to the Macedonians, saying that Achaia has been ready since last year, and your zeal has stirred up most of them.

3.verse: But I am sending these brothers so that what we say in praise of you may not be an empty boast in this instance, that you may be ready just as I said you would be.

4.verse: Lest perhaps if some Macedonians should come with me and not find you ready, we—to say nothing of you—would be humiliated by this confidence.

5.verse: Therefore I considered it necessary to urge the brothers to go to you in advance and to arrange beforehand the generous contribution you had previously promised, so that it would be ready as a generous gift and not as something you had to do.

6.verse: Remember this: the one who sows sparingly will also reap sparingly, and the one who sows generously will also reap generously.

7.verse: Each one must give as he has decided in his heart, not reluctantly nor under constraint, for it is the cheerful giver whom God loves.

8.verse: And God is able to make all grace overflow to you, so that, in all things and at all times, having all you need, you may overflow in every kind of good work.

9.verse: As it is written, “He has distributed generously, he has given to the poor; his righteousness endures for all time.”

10.verse: The one who supplies seed to the sower and bread for food will supply and multiply your seed and enlarge the harvest of your righteousness.

11.verse: In every way you will be made rich for all your generosity, which is producing through us thanksgiving to God,

12.verse: because the service of this ministry is not only providing for the needs of the saints, but is also overflowing through many thanksgivings to God.

13.verse: By their approval of this service, they glorify God for your obedience stemming from your confession in the gospel of Christ, and for the generosity of your partnership with them and with everyone.

14.verse: And in their prayers on your behalf they yearn for you because of the surpassing grace of God bestowed on you.

15.verse: Thanks be to God for his inexpressible gift!

1.verse: Now I, Paul myself, appeal to you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ—I who when present am “timid” among you, but when away am “bold” toward you.

2.verse: I ask that when I am present I may not have to be “bold,” with such a confidence as I expect I will dare to use against those who think that we are walking according to the flesh.

3.verse: For though we walk in the flesh, we are not waging war according to the flesh,

4.verse: for the weapons of our warfare are not of the flesh, but are empowered by God for tearing down strongholds. We tear down arguments

5.verse: and every lofty idea that is raised against the knowledge of God, and we take captive every thought to make it obey Christ.

6.verse: And we are ready to avenge every act of disobedience, whenever your obedience becomes complete.

7.verse: You are looking at outward appearances. If anyone has persuaded himself that he belongs to Christ, he should remind himself that just as he belongs to Christ, so also do we.

8.verse: For even if I boast about it, and more than that, about the authority which the Lord gave us for building you up and not for tearing you down, I will not be ashamed.

9.verse: I do not want to seem as though I am trying to frighten you with my letters.

10.verse: For some are saying, “His letters are weighty and forceful, but his physical presence is weak, and his rhetoric amounts to nothing.”

11.verse: Let such a person consider this, that what we are in word through letters when absent, such we also are in act when present.

12.verse: For we would not dare to classify or compare ourselves with some of those who are recommending themselves. Rather, when they measure themselves by themselves and compare themselves by themselves, they are without understanding.

13.verse: We, however, will not boast beyond proper limits, but only within the measure of the sphere of action which God has assigned to us as a measure, extending even as far as you.

14.verse: For it is not as though we had not come to you, over-reaching ourselves, for we did come even as far as you with the gospel of Christ.

15.verse: We will not go beyond proper limits by boasting in the labors of others, but we have hope that as your faith continues to grow, our area of activity among you will be greatly enlarged,

16.verse: so that we may preach the gospel in places beyond you, not boasting about the work already done in another person’s territory.

17.verse: But rather, “Let the one who boasts, boast in the Lord.”

18.verse: For it is not the one who recommends himself who is approved, but the one whom the Lord recommends.

1.verse: O that you would put up with me in a little foolishness! Do put up with me!

2.verse: For I am jealous for you with a jealousy God inspires, for I have promised you in marriage to a single husband, to Christ, that I might present you to him as an undefiled virgin.

3.verse: But I am afraid, however, that just as the serpent deceived Eve by his craftiness, so your minds may be led astray from the simplicity and purity that is in Christ.

4.verse: For if one comes and proclaims a different Jesus whom we did not proclaim, or if you welcome a different spirit which you did not welcome, or a different gospel which you did not welcome, you put up with it easily.

5.verse: For I consider myself to be in no way inferior to those “super-apostles.”

6.verse: But even if I am an amateur in speaking, I am certainly not in knowledge. Rather, in every way we have made this plain to you as to all.

7.verse: Or did I commit a sin in humbling myself so that you could be exalted, because I proclaimed the gospel of God to you without a charge?

8.verse: I robbed other churches, taking support from them to carry out my service to you.

9.verse: And when I was present with you and in need, I did not burden anyone, for when the brothers came from Macedonia they supplied my need. I kept myself from being a burden to you in any way, and will continue to do so.

10.verse: As the truth of Christ is in me, this boasting of mine will not be put to silence in the districts of Achaia.

11.verse: Why is that? Is it because I do not love you? God knows I do.

12.verse: And what I am doing I will continue to do, so as to remove any opportunity from those desiring an opportunity to be regarded, in the things in which they boast, to be just as we are.

13.verse: For such men are false apostles, deceitful workers, disguising themselves as apostles of Christ.

14.verse: And no wonder! For Satan himself disguises himself as an angel of light.

15.verse: So it is no great surprise if his servants, too, disguise themselves as servants of righteousness. Their end will be according to their works.

16.verse: Again I say, let no one think me foolish. But even if you do, then at least accept me as a fool, so that I too may boast a little.

17.verse: What I am saying, I am not saying according to the Lord, but as in foolishness, in this confidence of boasting.

18.verse: Since there are many who are boasting according to the flesh, I too will boast.

19.verse: For gladly you put up with fools, since you are so wise!

20.verse: For you put up with it if anyone enslaves you, if anyone exploits you, if anyone takes advantage of you, if anyone puts on airs, if anyone strikes you in the face.

21.verse: I say this to my shame, that in this we have been weak. But as to whatever anyone else dares to boast about—I am talking like a fool—I also dare to boast.

22.verse: Are they Hebrews? So am I. Are they Israelites? So am I. Are they descendants of Abraham? So am I.

23.verse: Are they servants of Christ?—I am talking like a madman!—I am even more so: in far more labors, in prison more often, in beatings more severe, facing death again and again.

24.verse: Five times I received from the Jews the forty lashes less one.

25.verse: Three times I was beaten with a rod. Once I was stoned. Three times I was shipwrecked. I have been adrift on the open sea for twenty-four hours.

26.verse: On my frequent journeys I have been exposed to dangers from rivers, dangers from bandits, dangers from my own people, dangers from Gentiles, dangers in the city, dangers in the countryside, dangers at sea, dangers at the hands of false brothers;

27.verse: in toil and hard work, often in need of sleep, in hunger and thirst, many times without food, in cold and nakedness.

28.verse: Apart from other things, there is the daily pressure on me of my anxious concern for all the churches.

29.verse: Who is weak, and I am not weak? Who is made to stumble, and I do not burn with indignation?

30.verse: If there must be boasting, I will boast of the things that display my weakness.

31.verse: The God and Father of our Lord Jesus, he who is blessed for all time, knows that I am not lying.

32.verse: At Damascus the ethnarch under king Aretas was guarding the city of Damascus in order to arrest me,

33.verse: but I was lowered in a basket through an opening in the wall and escaped his hands.

1.verse: It is necessary for me to continue boasting. Though it is not profitable, I will go on to visions and revelations from the Lord.

2.verse: I know a man in Christ who fourteen years ago—whether in the body I do not know or apart from the body I do not know, only God knows—such a man was caught up to the third heaven.

3.verse: And I know that this man—whether in the body or apart from the body I do not know, only God knows—

4.verse: that he was caught up into paradise and heard unspeakable words which are not permitted for a man to utter.

5.verse: On behalf of this man I will boast, but on my own behalf I will not boast, except in my weakness.

6.verse: For even if I should choose to boast, I would not be foolish, because I would be telling the truth. But I refrain from this, so that no one will give credit to me beyond what he sees in me or he hears from me,

7.verse: especially because of the extraordinary character of my revelations. Therefore in order that I should not become conceited, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, a messenger of Satan to torment me, that I should not become conceited.

8.verse: Three times I pleaded with the Lord about this, that it would leave me.

9.verse: But he said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is fulfilled in weakness.” Therefore I will most gladly boast in my weaknesses, in order that the power of Christ may dwell in me.

10.verse: For this reason I am content with weaknesses, with insults, with hardships, with persecutions and difficulties for the sake of Christ; for whenever I am weak, then I am strong.

11.verse: I am acting like a fool, but you drove me to it. I ought to be commended by you, for in no way am I inferior to the “super-apostles”—even though I am nothing.

12.verse: The marks of an apostle were done among you with all persistence, along with signs and wonders and powerful deeds.

13.verse: For in what way were you less favored than the rest of the churches, except that I myself was not a burden to you? Forgive me this injustice!

14.verse: Look, for the third time I am ready to come to you, and I will not be a burden, because I am not seeking what you have, but you. For children ought not save up for their parents, but the parents for the children.

15.verse: I will most gladly spend and be spent on behalf of your souls. If I love you more, am I to be loved less?

16.verse: But be that as it may, I did not burden you; yet being crafty, I took you in by deceit!

17.verse: I did not take advantage of you through anyone I sent to you, did I?

18.verse: I urged Titus to visit you and I sent the brother with him. Titus did not take advantage of you, did he? Did we not conduct ourselves in the same spirit? Did we not behave in the same way?

19.verse: Have you been thinking all along that we are defending ourselves to you? We are speaking before God as those in Christ; and all that we do, dear friends, is for your upbuilding.

20.verse: For I am afraid that perhaps when I come I may find you not as I would wish, and that I may be found by you not as you would wish; perhaps there will be strife, jealousy, flaring anger, selfish ambition, backbiting, gossiping, conceit, disorder.

21.verse: I am afraid that when I come, my God may again humble me before you, and that I will mourn for many who have sinned earlier and have not repented of the impurity, sexual immorality, and debauchery in which they indulged.

1.verse: This will be my third visit to you. On the evidence of two or three witnesses every accusation is to be confirmed.

2.verse: I said before when I was with you the second time, and now, though absent, I say ahead of time to those who have sinned previously and to all the rest, that if I come again I will not spare anyone,

3.verse: since you seek proof that Christ is speaking through me. He is not weak toward you but is powerful among you.

4.verse: For indeed he was crucified in weakness, but he lives by the power of God. For indeed we are weak in him, but we will live with him by the power of God toward you.

5.verse: Examine yourselves to see if you are in the faith. Test yourselves. Or do you not realize about yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you?—unless, of course, you fail the test!

6.verse: And I hope that you will find out that we do not fail the test!

7.verse: Now we pray to God that you may not do anything wrong, not that we would appear as having passed the test, but that you may do what is right even though we may appear as having failed.

8.verse: For we are not able to do anything against the truth, but only for the truth.

9.verse: For we rejoice whenever we are weak, but you are strong. And this is what we pray for, your Christian maturity.

10.verse: Therefore I write these things while I am absent, so that when I am present I may not have to treat you harshly according to the authority which the Lord gave me for building up and not tearing down.

11.verse: Finally, brothers, rejoice, strive for maturity, take courage, be like-minded, live in peace; and the God of love and peace will be with you.

12.verse: Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the saints send you their greetings.

13.verse: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ and the love of God and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all.

14.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version
